newsitem.title: USA: Russia, Bulgaria debt surge in slow LDC debt trade.
newsitem.headline: Russia, Bulgaria debt surge in slow LDC debt trade.

text.p: Emerging market debt prices rose Monday on the back of a surging U.S. Treasury market and bullish sentiment about Russia and Bulgaria's prospects, Brady bond traders said.
"There was ongoing support from Treasury side, which was the most important factor for the whole Brady market," said Kurt Schmid, managing director at SBC Warburg.
Eastern European paper, particularly Russian and Bulgarian, surged amid ongoing bullishness over the countries' prospects.

"Russia is very cheap, it's probably the cheapest country in the market relative to its credit rating," said Gary Evans, global debt strategist at UBS Securities. "There's not doubt the fundamentals were improving in Bulgaria, but in Bulgaria the assets were undervalued in the first place."
Bulgaria FLRBs BGFLIRB=RR jumped 2-1/4 to 58-3/8, whi;e Bulgaria Discounts BGFLTH24A=RR soared 2-1/4 tp 75-1/4.
Russian mark-denominated Vnesh loans RUVNUSLNS=RR climbed 1-1/8 to 97-/8.
The benchmark 30-year U.S. Treasury bond rose 13/32 to yield 6.70 percent.
Bulgarian paper also prospered from talk that the country's policymakers were involved with international investment bankers about a potential restructuring of its Brady bonds.
"People are trying to position themselves in anticipation," one U.S. investor said.
Not all market players readily believed that Bulgaria had changed so dramatically since it presented its plans for economic reform and pegging the lev to the German mark.
"All boats rise with the tide," one Brady trader said. "I haven't heard any news that would prompt me to think that (Bulgaria) has its act together any more than it did six months ago."
Among Latin American issues, Argentine FRBs ARFLC05=RR slipped 1/8 to 94-1/4, while Brazilian Cs BR8D14=RR closed up 1/4 to 81-5/8.
